content.original:
The Roman dynasty was spread over many decades, and gave rise to some of the longest living systems of law, architecture, etc. Read on for a list of all the rulers of this great empire…
The history of the ancient empire of Rome has always managed to fascinate us. The Roman empire derives its origin from the Roman Republic after its ascent to the dominant power in Europe. Thus, Augustus, who is universally considered the first Roman emperor, was careful to always maintain the facade of republican rule, and did not take up any specific title to mark his rule, which began in 27 B.C. Given below is a list starting with Augustus until Justin II.
List of Roman Emperors
- Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus
- Tiberius Julius Caesar Augustus
- Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Tiberius Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Servius Sulpicius Galba
- Marcus Salvius Otho
- Aulus Vitellius Germanicus
- Titus Flavius Vespasianus
- Titus Flavius Vespasianus
- Titus Flavius Domitianus
- Marcus Cocceius Nerva

- Titus Aurelius Fulvus Boionius Arrius Antoninus (Antoninus Pius)

- Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus

- Lucius Septimius Severus

- Marcus Aurelius Severus Alexander
- Gaius Iulius Verus Maximinus (Maximinus I)
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Sempronianus Romanus Africanus (Gordian I)
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Sempronianus Romanus Africanus (Gordian II)

- Decimus Caelius Calvinus Balbinus
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Pius (Gordian III)
- Marcus Julius Philippus (Philip the Arab)
- Gaius Messius Quintus Decius
- Gaius Valens Hostilianus Messius Quintus
- Gaius Vibius Trebonianus Gallus

- Publius Licinius Valerianus
- Publius Licinius Egnatius Gallienus
- Marcus Aurelius Claudius
- Marcus Aurelius Claudius Quintillus
- Lucius Domitius Aurelianus
- Marcus Claudius Tacitus
- Marcus Annius Florianus
- Marcus Aurelius Probus
- Marcus Aurelius Carus
- Marcus Aurelius Numerius Numerianus
- Marcus Aurelius Carinus
- Gaius Aurelius Valerius Diocletianus
- Marcus Aurelius Valerius Maximianus Herculius
- Flavius Valerius Constantius (Constantius Chlorus)

- Flavius Valerius Severus
- Caesar Flavius Valerius Aurelius Constantinus Augustus (Constantine I or Emperor Constantine)
- Marcus Aurelius Valerius Maxentius
- Gaius Valerius Galerius Maximinus (Maximinus II)
- Valerius Licinianus Licinius
- Flavius Claudius Constantinus (Constantine II)
- Flavius Iulius Constantius (Constantius II)
- Flavius Julius Constans
- Flavius Claudius Iulianus (Julian the Apostate)
- Flavius Iovianus (Jovian)
- Flavius Valentinianus
- Flavius Julius Valens
- Flavius Gratianus
- Flavius Valentinianus (Valentinian II)
- Theodosius I
- Flavius Arcadius
- Flavius Honorius
- Flavius Theodosius (Theodosius II)
- Flavius Constantius (Constantius III)
- Joannes
- Flavius Placidius Valentinianus (Valentinian III)
- Flavius Marcianus
- Flavius Petronius Maximus
- Eparchius Avitus
- Flavius Iulius Valerius Maiorianus
- Flavius Libius Severus Serpentius
- Procopius Anthemius
- Anicius Olybrius
- Glycerius
- Julius Nepos
- Romulus Augustus
- Flavius Valerius Leo (Leo I the Thracian)
- Flavius Leo Junior (Leo II)
- Flavius Zeno
- Flavius Basiliscus
- Flavius Anastasius
- Flavius Iustinus (Justin I)
- Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus (Justinian I)
- Flavius Iustinus (Junior) Augustus (Justin II)
Even though Romulus Augustus is considered to have been the last Roman emperor, he was actually an usurper, and is not included in the list. The decline of the Roman empire occurred due to increasingly strong enemies and treachery within the empire. However, no one can deny them the various achievements that marked the era, like their art, literature and architecture.
content.optimized:
The Roman Empire: Historical Significance and Legacy
----------------------------------------------------

The Roman Empire, originating from the Roman Republic, spanned many decades and established some of the longest-lasting systems in law, architecture, and culture. Its history continues to fascinate, marked by significant achievements that shaped Western civilization and left a profound and enduring legacy in art, literature, governance, and architecture.

Augustus: The First Roman Emperor
---------------------------------

Augustus, universally recognized as the first Roman emperor, began his rule in 27 B.C. Despite his authority, he carefully maintained the appearance of republican traditions and avoided adopting any specific imperial title, preserving the facade of the Roman Republic even as he consolidated power.

List of Roman Emperors (From Augustus to Justin II)
---------------------------------------------------

- Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus

Decline and Enduring Achievements
---------------------------------

The decline of the Roman Empire was driven by a combination of internal strife, including treachery, and increasing pressure from strong external enemies. Despite these challenges, the empire’s remarkable contributions to law, architecture, culture, art, literature, and governance continue to be celebrated and studied for their enduring influence on the modern world.

Recommended Online Courses on Roman History
-------------------------------------------

To further explore the rich history of the Roman Empire, several online courses offer comprehensive insights into its law, culture, and architecture. Notable courses include:

- **"The Roman Empire: From Augustus to the Fall of Rome"** (Coursera) – Covers the political and cultural history of Rome, helping learners understand the empire’s governance and societal structure through video lectures, readings, and quizzes.

- **"Roman Architecture"** (edX) – Focuses on the engineering marvels and architectural innovations of the Romans, including the use of concrete and monumental structures, featuring interactive assignments and virtual tours.

- **"Ancient Rome: A History in Seven Hills"** (FutureLearn) – Explores Rome’s cultural and historical development, emphasizing its lasting influence on Western civilization, combining video content with discussion forums and written assessments.

These courses equip learners with skills in historical analysis, critical thinking, and an appreciation of Roman contributions to modern law, architecture, and culture, making them ideal for anyone interested in the empire’s enduring legacy.
